column1: #Text=mysql - MariaDB 10.2 Performance Tuning - Lock wait timeout Issues - Stack Overflow

#Text=“If there is one thing developers like less than writing documentation, it’s responding to unnecessary escalations […] and too many escalations wear down the developers.”
#Text=Tom LimoncelliSite Reliability Engineering Manager at Stack Overflow
#Text=“We needed a better place to store all the questions and answers that people were repeatedly asking, and we discovered Stack Overflow for Teams.”
#Text=Suyog RaoDirector of Engineering at Elastic Cloud
#Text=“We use Stack Overflow for Teams internally when onboarding new developers, and when new developers ask questions, everyone can benefit from the shared knowledge.”
#Text=Roberta ArcoverdePrincipal Software Developer at Stack Overflow
#Text=– Collaborate and share knowledge with a private group.
#Text=Connect and share knowledge within a single location that is structured and easy to search.
#Text=MariaDB 10.2 Performance Tuning - Lock wait timeout Issues
#Text=I have 4 instance database-clustering (2 of them are mariadb 10.2 server and 2 of them is garbd server)
#Text=We use update-heavy queries in our databases, dealing with a huge tables which some of the tables have over 20 million records.
#Text=Also we have lots of java application which use database and these threads mostly make "update" processes in tables.
#Text=In the peak_time we use about 200 threads.
#Text=Our problem is that we have "Deadlock" in our applications.
#Text=I believe that I can figure out by making some performance tuning in database configurations.
#Text=These are also configured in second server, too with a server-id=2 and db2.pid, db2.err changes.
#Text=Is these changes might solve my problem?
#Text=I want to know that these parameters are well-configured ?
#Text=We have 32 GB RAM (8-core) in the servers.
#Text=To discuss deadlocks and lock-wait-timeout, we need to see the conflicting transactions, plus SHOW CREATE TABLE.
#Text=Any SSD or NVME devices on MySQL Host server?
#Text=Post on pastebin.com and share the links.
#Text=From your SSH login root, Text results of:
#Text=after minimum 24 hours UPTIME C) SHOW GLOBAL VARIABLES;
#Text=D) SHOW FULL PROCESSLIST; E) complete MySQLTuner report
#Text=AND Optional very helpful information, if available includes -
#Text=iostat -xm 5 3\tfor IOPS by device and core/cpu count,
#Text=for server workload tuning analysis to provide suggestions.
#Text=I'm guessing nnodb_write_io_threads is a typo as mysqld wouldn't start with it.
#Text=I would start with innodb_thread_concurrency = 0 to de-restrict the thread concurrency throttling.
#Text=Are your UPDATEs running fully indexed, ideally with PK in the WHERE?
#Text=Is there a good reason you have innodb_file_per_table commented out?
#Text=It might be worth verifying that your table_open_cache isn't too small (look at the process list and see if you regularly see queries in state of "opening|closing tables".
#Text=Are these servers VMs, and are they on a busy/overbooked host?
#Text=I have seen very interesting spurious deadlocks in situations where clock ticks are unstable and unpredictable, e.g. on heavily overbooked virtual machines.
#Text=There is some interesting thread racing happening under those conditions that seems to be completely un-reproducible on bare metal.
#Text=Bumping up the instance size in the cloud environment usually cures the problem because bigger instances tend to be on less overbooked hosts.
#Text=I have corrected my typo and changed my configuration files as innodb_thread_concurrency = 0 as you mentioned.
#Text=I tried to configure very low-performing-consuming parameters and I have read about that innodb_file_per_table parameters could effect the RAM usage, so I decided to comment it out.
#Text=Actually I couldn't figure out what this parameters use for clearly.
#Text=Let me tell you my some observation after I have restarted both DB servers.
#Text=First of all I stopped all application that making connection to db-1 (Actually we are making all db connections through DB1), then restarted both DB-servers.
#Text=First of all, let me clear that there was no any traffic when I started applications.
#Text=After I start all appcalitons that we use, I realised that I was seeing about 120 processes that created by our user in PROCESSLIST in the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.
#Text=Also I know that some of these connections don't make anything but using connnection_pool.
#Text=I was set up 100s wait_timeout, after 100s later, PROCESSLIST down to "27" and threads_cache became 92.

#Text=I also know that these 27 connection was used by some applications that running some check queries in spesific time interval. (10sec, 4sec, 2sec) So when they run queries , their connection_time return 0 and count again as they are never closed.
#Text=I believe that in the peak_time, we are gonna need thread_cache_size, so configuring this parameter as 256 would be good for our system.
#Text=I know it is so hard to understand for now but can you please check my innodb engine status and give me some advice as I am not very good at concept of database management systems.

#Text=Current read_rnd_buffer_size = 256 M - indicates your rrbs is 256Meg.
#Text=for a 256K rrbs to significantly reduce handler_read_rnd_next RPS.
#Text=In your my.cnf make the change for future more reasonable RAM usage and to reduce CPU busy.
#Text=I think default value for this parameters is 256K, right ?
#Text=You are correct, read_rnd_buffer_size in MariaDB reference manual is 256K.
